info.game_comments:
Bernie Cullen game 1.
First game of Season 13.

(1, 1).clue: "Linda's Kitchen" is a vegetarian cookbook by this wife of a former Beatle

(2, 1).clue: This name was especially popular in the 1800s, when a certain Miss Dickinson and Miss Bronte were born

(3, 1).clue: According to the Magickal Almanac, this is the only country where a black cat is considered bad luck

(4, 1).clue: This city is the seat of Washington's King County

(5, 1).clue: France's Marie-Jose Perec won the women's 200- & 400-meter runs, & this American became the 1st man to win both

(6, 1).clue: When Abel Tasman discovered this island in 1642, he called it Van Diemen's Land

(1, 2).clue: Robert K. Massie concluded his saga of this royal couple in "The Romanovs: The Final Chapter"

(2, 2).clue: Actress Bergman helped popularize this Scandinavian first name, possibly meaning "beautiful"

(3, 2).clue: Don't ask a fisherman this question; if he answers, it'll stop his streak

(4, 2).clue: The name of this state's Kennebec River is Algonquian for "long reach"

(5, 2).clue: Karch Kiraly became the only player to win a 3rd gold medal in this sport, indoors or out

(6, 2).clue: The Chinese plan called the Great Leap Forward was initiated by this leader in 1958

(1, 3).clue: This Microsoft CEO talks about the future of computers in his bestseller "The Road Ahead"

(2, 3).clue: The name Perdita was created by this playwright for the heroine of his "Winter's Tale"

(3, 3).clue: In pagan Ireland this plant was a symbol of the 3 aspects of this goddess

(4, 3).clue: The geographic center of this state lies in Wexford County, 5 miles north-northwest of Cadillac

(5, 3).clue: On July 19, 1996 Janet Evans lit his fire

(6, 3).clue: In 1986 this dictator fled Haiti, ending 28 years of rule by his family

(1, 4).clue: This family of anthropologists is the subject of the biography "Ancestral Passions"

(2, 4).clue: Dominique is traditional for a girl born on this day of the week

(3, 4).clue: For a bride, a coin in here ensures future wealth & perhaps a painful walk down the aisle

(4, 4).clue: The largest area of sand dunes in North America lies north of the Platte River in this state

(5, 4).clue: Nickname of Turkey's gold medal-winning weightlifter Naim Suleymanoglu

(6, 4).clue: In 405 B.C. Spartan commander Lysander won the final victory over the Athenians in this war

(1, 5).clue: "Years of Upheaval" is his personal account of foreign affairs during President Nixon's 2nd term

(2, 5).clue: Lolita is a pet form of Lola & Lola is a pet form of this name, Spanish for "sorrows"

(3, 5).clue: Finding & carrying a rusty one of these is luckier than a shiny one…just don't step on it

(4, 5).clue: Over 3 dozen mountains in this northern New York range exceed 4,000 feet

(5, 5).clue: As it turned out, the U.S. didn't need the points from her 2nd vault, which worsened her ankle injury

(6, 5).clue: In 1358 Lubeck, on the Baltic coast, became the headquarters of this league

(1, 1).clue: The U.S. will stop operating this 50-mile-long passageway in the year 2000

(2, 1).clue: Before starting the Pennsylvania Gazette in 1729, he worked for nearly a year in a London printing office

(3, 1).clue: In 1995 she reprised her role of Victor/Victoria for the Broadway stage

(4, 1).clue: This South American river has more than a thousand known tributaries

(5, 1).clue: In 1726 this "Messiah" composer became an English citizen

(6, 1).clue: The titles Kaiser & Czar were both derived from this earlier title

(1, 2).clue: The 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake did little damage to this, the world's tallest suspension bridge

(2, 2).clue: At age 19 this "Leaves of Grass" author became editor of The Long Islander, a weekly newspaper

(3, 2).clue: She's played 2 Stephen King characters on film: Annie Wilkes in "Misery" & "Dolores Claiborne"

(4, 2).clue: Lake Manapouri on South Island is one of this country's deepest lakes

(5, 2).clue: Although known as "The Waltz King", he also wrote numerous marches & polkas

(6, 2).clue: Pants, as an item of apparel, is short for this word, from an Italian comic character

(1, 3).clue: Built in 410 days, it was the tallest building in the world for 4 decades of the 20th century

(2, 3).clue: In 1805 this explorer was sent to take a "peak" at the upper Mississippi

(3, 3).clue: In a 1995 film this Irish actor portrayed Scottish outlaw Rob Roy

(4, 3).clue: Bordered by Ukraine & Russia, the Sea of Azov is a northern arm of this sea

(5, 3).clue: His 1742 "Aria with Thirty Variations" is usually called the "Goldberg Variations"

(6, 3).clue: Dating from the 16th century, goodbye is a contraction of these 4 words

(1, 4).clue: The Itaipu, one of these 5 miles wide on the Brazil-Paraguay border, inspired a Philip Glass symphony

(2, 4).clue: When he left office in 1987, this Democrat had served an unprecedented 4 terms as Alabama governor

(3, 4).clue: He directed live-in love Susan Sarandon in the movie "Dead Man Walking"

(4, 4).clue: Hellespont is the ancient name for this strait that connects the Sea of Marmara with the Aegean Sea

(5, 4).clue: Shortly after this "Gretchen am Spinnrade" composer met Beethoven, he was a torchbearer at his funeral

(6, 4).clue: Copper was named for this island where it was abundant

(1, 5).clue: It runs between the towns of Folkestone & Coquelles

(2, 5).clue: In 1780 this "Swamp Fox" was appointed Brigadier General of the South Carolina militia

(3, 5).clue: Deborah Zerby is the real name of this actress who starred in "True Grit"

(4, 5).clue: This "Great" lake is the largest lake entirely within Canada

(5, 5).clue: This "Grand Canyon Suite" composer was once and arranger & pianist for Paul Whiteman

(6, 5).clue: Coined by a 9-year-old circa 1940, it's a 1 followed by 100 zeros

(0, 0).clue: The preface to this 1913 play was entitled "A Professor of Phonetics"
